paragraph.paragraph: Eiffel for Visual Studio.NET provides the facilities to modify your projects setting via a number of property pages. The property pages can be used to modify a single projects configuration (debug, release, etc), modify all configurations in a project, modify the configurations of multiple projects in a multiple project solution, and even multiple configurations for multiple projects.
paragraph.heading: 2Understanding The Property Page Dialog
paragraph.paragraph:
The property page dialog is a common dialog to Visual Studio, it allows the manipulate of your projects setting.To discover what each one of the property pages does see the below section
property_pages The Property Pages .
paragraph.heading: 2Viewing in multiple configuration modes:
paragraph.paragraph: There are two ways that a projects properties can be manipulated. Firstly there's single configuration. This is a single selected project, where the configuration property is set to either debug or release (or any other configuration added to the project). The alternative way is to manipulate multiple configurations. This is can be a single project with the configuration property set to 'All Configurations' and/or multiple projects in the solution are selected.

When viewing in multiple configurations some previously entered values (in a single configuration) may not be display, or displayed correctly. This is normal as the property page cannot find a common value for each one of the configurations and so leaves it blank or replaces the value with a value that represents different values. And example of this would be to have two projects in a solution. ProjectA and ProjectB . The system names (
general_ppg.xml General Property Page ) for these projects are ProjectA and ProjectB respectively. When each one of the projects is selected individually the general property page will display the respective system name. However if both projects are selected when viewing their properties the system name will not display anything as the two system names are different. If we were then to change this value, then both ProjectA's and ProjectB's system name will be changed to new value.
paragraph.warning:
Recommended : It is recommended that when making additions to your project(s) that the 'All Configurations' be selected in the configuration drop down list box on the property page dialog. This is so you can ensure that when adding a cluster, assembly reference, external or setting any other basic property, all configurations will have these changes. If these settings where to be made in a single configurations, then you will have to switch to each one of the other configurations and reapply the settings for each. Each one of the configurations modes (such as debug, release etc.) should be reserved for use in setting configuration specific properties. An example of a configuration specific property would be
debugging_ppg.xmlgenerate_debug_info Generate Debug Info in the
debugging_ppg.xml Debugging Property Page .. For a release configuration there is no need to generate the debugging information, as your project has already been debugged and is read to be released.
paragraph.heading: 2Saving Your Configuration
paragraph.paragraph: To save all of the changes made in the property pages click on the Apply or OK button located at the bottom right of the property page dialog.
paragraph.warning: Note: Unless stated, any changes to the properties in the property pages require a system re-compilation to reflect those changes made.
paragraph.heading: 2Switch Configurations and Projects
paragraph.paragraph:
The property page dialog is a non-modal window so you are able to change the project that is being configured to another project, simply click clicking on the desired project node in the
/10_Developing\10_Getting_Started\10_Using_ENViSioN\20_Solution_Explorer\index.xml Solution Explorer . The property page will automatically update with the newly selected project settings. If any unsaved changes have been made to the previous project, then you will be asked to save those project settings before the project configurations are switched.
paragraph.heading: 2The Property Pages
paragraph.paragraph: In total there are seven independently configurable property pages for an Eiffel ENViSioN! project.

list.item: General - For all of the general (basic) project properties.
Assembly Info - Information about the project (version number, description etc.).
Assertions - The project wide Design By Contract settings.
Clusters - Allows manipulation of the projects clusters.
Externals - All of the object files and include paths for the project.
Debugging - The debugging options for the project.
